questions.text: A 45-year-old patient underwent a lap cholecystectomy for gallstones. On day 2 in the postoperative period, he experienced fever and pain in the right hypochondrium. Ultrasonography revealed 200cc of fluid in the GB fossa. What is your next step?

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient presenting with fever and right hypochondrial pain post-cholecystectomy, accompanied by fluid collection on ultrasound, the initial step should be ultrasound-guided drainage. This minimally invasive approach can effectively manage a bile leak, which is a recognized complication after gallbladder surgery. Further diagnostic and therapeutic measures, such as ERCP, MRCP, or surgical intervention, depend on the clinical evolution and findings after the initial drainage.

questions.text: Following head trauma, a patient opens eyes to pain, localizes pain on the right shoulder but withdraws on the left side, and speaks incoherent words. His GCS is?

Ans. C) 10

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Glasgow Coma Scale is a critical tool for assessing the level of consciousness in patients with head injuries. A GCS score of 10 indicates moderate head injury, necessitating close monitoring and potentially more intensive medical intervention.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male was brought to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. He is unconscious and shows signs of head trauma. The patient’s initial examination reveals bradycardia, hypertension, and irregular respirations. A CT scan of the head shows significant cerebral edema. What is the term for the sequential events following head trauma that lead to the coning of the medulla and death?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Rostro-caudal decay

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rostro-caudal decay involves the sequential neurological deterioration from the cerebral cortex through the brainstem due to increasing intracranial pressure, leading to herniation and death. Recognizing and managing increased intracranial pressure promptly is crucial in preventing this fatal progression.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male smoker presents with painless hematuria. Further investigation reveals bladder cancer extending up to the muscle layer. What should be the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For muscle-invasive bladder cancer, the treatment of choice is radical cystectomy, which involves the removal of the bladder and surrounding tissues to achieve the best long-term outcomes. Painless hematuria in a smoker is highly suggestive of bladder carcinoma and should prompt thorough evaluation.
